word noun
(LANGUAGE UNIT)
Add to word list
Add to word list
A1 [ C ] a single unit of language that has meaning and can be spoken or written: Your essay should be no more than two thousand words long. Some words are more difficult to spell than others. What's the word for bikini in French? It's sometimes difficult to find exactly the right word to express what you want to say. the F-word, C-word, etc.
used to refer to a word, usually a rude or embarrassing one, by saying only the first letter and not the whole word: You're still not allowed to say the F-word on TV in the US So how's the diet going - or would you rather I didn't mention the d-word? I know Maisie very well and I know that she would never say the C-word. Surely he didn't say the F-word? Am I allowed to mention the E-word and ask when your exams start?

word noun
(TALKING)
B2 [ S ] a short discussion or statement: The manager wants a word. Could I have a word (with you) about the sales figures? Could you have a quiet word with Mike (= gently explain to him) about the problem? words [ plural ]
disapproving discussion, rather than action: So far there have been more words than action on the matter of childcare provision. exchange words
If two or more people exchange words, they talk to each other for a short time: Nurses went busily up and down, sometimes pausing to exchange words. We exchanged a few words as we were coming out of the meeting. There is no evidence the pair even exchanged words on that occasion, let alone knew each other well.
If two people or groups exchange words, they have an argument with each other: Words were exchanged and then someone threw a punch. Angry words were exchanged outside the meeting room. He became agitated and exchanged words with the man. Synonym
have words have words
If two people or groups have words, they have an argument with each other: I think they had words after we left. I don't know if Amber is talking to me - we had words this morning. Synonym
exchange words have words with someone
mainly UK to speak angrily to someone because they have done something wrong : Her father would have had words with her about that. At the end of the game I had words with the referee but I immediately apologized afterwards. Synonym
tell someone off a good word
a statement of approval and support for someone or something: If you see the captain could you put in a good word for me? The critics didn't have a good word to say about the performance. She doesn't have a good word to say about her hometown. No one seemed to have a good word to say for her - even her daughter. Beth had evidently put in a good word for us and we were greeted very warmly when we arrived.
